key_title: Key to the species of Asplenium

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1994). Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Lamina densely hairy with conspicuous glandular or non-glandular hairs both adaxially and abaxially; indusia absent
Lamina glabrous or with occasional minute hair-like scales abaxially; indusia present
Fronds divided more than once (sometimes only basal pinnae divided)
Pinnae margins doubly, and often deeply, toothed; apices finely tapering (presumed extinct in Victoria)
Pinnae margins with many blunt teeth or entire; apices rounded and obtuse or shortly acute
Lamina thick and fleshy; stipe and rachis with scales; pinnae mostly more than 15 mm long; coastal between the high tide mark and first line of trees and shrubs parallel to the sea
Lamina thin and herbaceous; stipe and rachis without scales; pinnae less than 15 mm long; inland or if coastal inland from first line of vegetation
Fronds prostrate or drooping, often taking root at tips of extended rachises; stipe and rachis slender, green or pale brown; pinnae fan-shaped
Fronds erect; stipe and rachis brittle, red-brown to blackish; pinnae broadly oblong, less than 10 mm long; rock dwelling
Fronds usually less than 20 cm, rarely longer; secondary pinnae with slender stalks; known only from subalps
Fronds often longer than 20 cm; secondary pinnae with short broad stalks or sessile; sea-level to subalps
All ultimate segments cuneate or obovate to almost rectangular and dissected near apex; all sori remote from margin with their indusia opening away from closest margin

Some ultimate segments ovate, elliptic, triangular, linear or oblong and tapering to a point rather than dissected at apex; at least some sori marginal with their indusia opening toward closest margin
Plants usually with at least some fronds producing bulbils; apices of pinnae and segments rounded to acute; lamina herbaceous to coriaceous
Fronds never producing bulbils; apices of pinnae and segments bluntly acute to acuminate; lamina coriaceous
All segments linear and a similar width to axes; epiphytic in Victoria
Some pinnae or segments narrowly ovate to elliptic and much wider than frond axes; lithophytic in Victoria
